result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Andrew J Derks

COURT GRANTS BW $250.00 and BF.

DATES:

Judicial Pretrial - in court on October 27, 2022 at 09:40 am.

Jury Trial on January 11, 2023 at 09:00 am.
No violent contact with victim(s): A.K.   Police escort to retrieve personal property from the residence.  Third party child exchange through the family resource center.

Clerk: Amanda.
Case called at 3:23 pm.
State appears by ADA Hannah Boeck. Defendant appears pro se.
Date and Time set for IA; VRCW. 

Reading Waived.  Reserve Jurisdiction. 
Court questions deft re: complaint and rights.
Advised Right of Counsel. 

PLEA:  NOT GUILTY.

A.K. makes statement. 

COURT ORDERS: $500 signature bond - CONDITIONS: 
- No violent contact with victim(s): A.K. Contact includes direct personal or physical and indirect contact by phone, in writing of any kind, entry to the person's residence or place of employment together with contacts through other persons.  Contact, however, may be made through the defendant's attorney.
- Police escort to retrieve personal property from the residence. 
- 3rd party child exchange through the family resource center.
